content: A book has 500 pages. You read 20 pages every day except on Sundays when you read 30 pages. How long will it take you to finish the book? Provide your logic.

Let's tackle this reading challenge! So, I've got a 500-page book, and I'm supposed to read 20 pages every day except on Sundays, when I read 30 pages. Hmm, okay, first things first, I need to figure out how many pages I read in a week.

There are 7 days in a week. If I read 20 pages each day from Monday to Saturday, that's 6 days, right? So, 6 days × 20 pages/day = 120 pages. Then on Sunday, I read 30 pages. So, in total, per week, I read 120 + 30 = 150 pages.

Now, the book has 500 pages. I need to find out how many weeks it'll take to read 500 pages at a rate of 150 pages per week.

500 ÷ 150 = 3.333... weeks. Hmm, but I can't have a fraction of a week. So, I need to see how many full weeks I can read and then see how many pages are left over.

In 3 full weeks, I read 3 × 150 = 450 pages. So, 500 - 450 = 50 pages left to read.

Now, after 3 weeks, I've read 450 pages, and I have 50 pages left. I need to figure out how many more days it'll take to read these 50 pages.

Remember, on weekdays (Monday to Saturday), I read 20 pages per day, and on Sunday, I read 30 pages.

So, let's see. If I have 50 pages left, and it's the start of a new week, I'll read 20 pages on Monday, leaving me with 50 - 20 = 30 pages.

Then on Tuesday, I'll read another 20 pages, but I only need 30 pages, so on Tuesday, I'll read the remaining 30 pages.

Wait, but hold on. On Sunday, I read 30 pages, but since it's a new week, maybe I should consider the days accordingly.

Let me clarify: after 3 full weeks of reading 150 pages each week, I have 50 pages left. Now, I need to see which day of the week it is, but maybe for simplicity, I can assume that the pattern repeats every week, so the days are the same each week.

Alternatively, I can think of it like this: in a week, I read 150 pages. After 3 weeks, 450 pages are read, leaving 50 pages.

Now, I need to read the remaining 50 pages. Let's see how many days that takes.

Day 1: 20 pages (Monday), total read: 450 + 20 = 470 pages, remaining: 50 - 20 = 30 pages.

Day 2: 20 pages (Tuesday), but I only need 30 pages, so I'll read 30 pages on Tuesday.

Wait, but I read 20 pages on Tuesday, but I only need 30 pages. Wait, that doesn't make sense.

Wait, no. After Monday, I've read 470 pages, and I have 30 pages left. On Tuesday, I read 20 pages, which would bring me to 490 pages, leaving 10 pages.

Then on Wednesday, I'll read another 20 pages, but I only need 10 pages, so I'll read 10 pages on Wednesday.

Wait, but that can't be right because 500 - 490 = 10 pages, not 30.

Let me recast this. After 3 weeks: 450 pages read.

Day 1 (Monday): +20 pages → 470 pages, 30 pages left.

Day 2 (Tuesday): +20 pages → 490 pages, 10 pages left.

Day 3 (Wednesday): +10 pages → 500 pages.

So, it takes 3 weeks and 3 days to finish the book.

So, in total, it's 3 weeks and 3 days.
